Quantum mechanics is a theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of phenomena. However, it is not a complete theory, and there are many problems that it cannot solve. One of the most important of these is the problem of measurement. In this paper, we show that the problem of measurement can be solved by adding a small amount of structure to the theory. This structure is very natural and is already present in the standard formulation of quantum mechanics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been suggested to be the result of a single evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian. However, the origin of this transition has remained elusive. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian, and we show that the myxozoan body plan is remarkably reduced in terms of both gene content and genome size. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the myxozoan transition was accompanied by a reduction in complexity, and that the resulting parasite is a simplified version of the ancestral cnidarian. This study provides a unique perspective on the origin of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The virus has evolved a strategy to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN), which is a key factor in the innate immune response. In this study, we show that the accessory protein ORF6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated factors (ISFs), which is a key step in the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that ORF6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex involved in nuclear import. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs the interaction between ORF6 and the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of crops, and the magnitude of the effect depends on the temperature at which the crop is grown. We quantify the effect of global warming on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. As a result, the probability that the major maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They underscore the need for global cooperation to mitigate climate change.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is critical to understanding the coexistence of species in natural ecosystems. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and many plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most important questions in presolar grain research. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that the majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This is important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. This work is a milestone in the field of presolar grain research. It will help to understand the formation of the solar system. It will also help to understand the formation of other stars.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The expansion of the motorized fleet is expected to continue in developing countries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of allomaternal care and domestication. Caspase-1 is a protease that is activated in the brain in response to inflammation. Caspase-1 is also expressed in neurons and has been implicated in the mechanisms that promote aggregation of α-syn in vitro and in neuronal cell models of α-syn toxicity. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are connected by a network of channels. The network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected to each other. The network is critical for the endothelium to respond to stimuli. Here, we show that the network is highly connected and that the cells are connected in a way that allows for rapid communication between them. The network is also scale-free, meaning that the number of connections between cells is not evenly distributed. This is a unique property of the endothelium and may be important for the endothelium’s ability to respond to stimuli.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for free to the public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for K+ over other ions. The selectivity filter is closed in the closed state and opened in the open state. The opening of the selectivity filter is coupled to the closing of the activation gate. We have identified a key residue that is involved in this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the opening of the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. In this study, we identify a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products in anaerobic fungi that are found in the gut. These fungi are a potential source of novel natural products that could be used to treat infections caused by bacteria. This study also provides a resource for the discovery of natural products in anaerobic fungi. This work is a step toward understanding the role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome and the potential for these fungi to be used therapeutically.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is mediated by the nucleus accumbens and that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism in this brain region. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to program mechanical devices to realize any desired response is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly with different elastomers with distinct behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to program mechanical devices to realize any desired response. It also opens up a new avenue to design and manufacture multifunctional devices with complex and navigable responses. This work is expected to inspire the development of programmable materials and devices with a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is developmentally regulated, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed in the fetus and newborn, and adult hemoglobin (HbA) being expressed in adults. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells. This is the first demonstration of a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The underlying molecular mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are not fully understood. Here, we show that the major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate STIM1, which in turn activates ORAI channels and promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral ecosystems, but that the decline of older forests accelerated. This is partly due to the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Therefore, the development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a computational approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility of acylide antibiotics. We tested the best candidates in vitro and in vivo. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher membrane permeability, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Thus, the approach presented here can be used to identify new antibiotics. This will help to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens and to prevent the development of antibiotic resistance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new architecture for deep convolutional neural networks that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train, and is more robust to changes in the training data. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the impact of such devices on sleep has not been well studied. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delights the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces the quality of sleep. These findings have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas chronozone marks a period of global climate change. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YD boundary. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YD boundary sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Os isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YD sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of a rare 2- to 5-mm diameter spherule indicate that its source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that an impact triggered the YD cooling. (Show more)

CTLA-4 is a well-known regulator of immune responses. However, its specific role in the development of autoimmune diseases is not fully understood. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but resulted in severe organ-specific autoimmunity. In addition, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4–deficient mice had more severe collagen-induced arthritis, they were protected against peptide-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases. It also provides a model for the study of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this success remains unclear. We show that the evolution of beetles was driven by the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and that the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes was critical to the diversification of specialized herbivores. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of beetles and their role in the global carbon cycle.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to mitigate the impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants on the global pandemic. This work can also be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and drugs.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the core and the core formation process. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, which is different from the previous assumption. This mechanism can solve the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is legal in some states, it remains illegal at the federal level. The drug’s legal status has led to a lack of research on the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). The reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana abuse. These findings have implications for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is uniquely equipped to process it. Here, we use the most powerful artificial neural networks to study the language processing mechanisms in the human brain. We find that the most powerful models predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in neural responses to sentences. Models’ fits to the next-word prediction task generalize across datasets and imaging modalities. Model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are learnable by artificial neural networks. This may have implications for the study of language in the brain, as well as for the study of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is not clear whether it is stable, i.e., whether it can be made to converge to a stable solution. We show that this is not the case. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where there is no algorithm that can compute a stable solution. This is a fundamental result that will have a major impact on the field of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the failure of science communication. The pandemic’s exponential growth is a key reason why it has spread so rapidly. Yet, the scientific community has repeatedly emphasized that this growth is not linear, but exponential. This is a well-known phenomenon in mathematics, but it is also a well-known psychological phenomenon. The classic experiment that is often cited to illustrate this phenomenon is a 1972 study by the psychologist Paul Meehl. However, the study’s design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study has been widely misinterpreted. This article discusses the flaws of the study and its consequences.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the peripheral nervous system (PNS) forms, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the diffuse forms. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome of a leprosy bacterium to be sequenced. We also compare the genomes of the two leprosy bacteria and find that they are very similar, despite causing different forms of leprosy. This suggests that the two leprosy bacteria have been evolving together for a very long time.

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum and statistical mechanics. They are also the keystones of quantum information theory. In the past few years, the study of quantum quenches revealed that these concepts are intricately intertwined. Although the unitary time evolution ensuing from a pure state maintains the system at zero entropy, local properties at long times are captured by a statistical ensemble with nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the entanglement accumulated during the dynamics. Therefore, understanding the entanglement evolution unveils how thermodynamics emerges in isolated systems. We show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement evolution, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only currently available vaccine against COVID-19 is based on the replication-defective adenovirus vector. However, this vaccine is expensive, requires refrigeration, and has the potential to cause severe adverse events. In this study, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is easy to manufacture, can be stored at room temperature, and is highly protective. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and mortality. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are bubonic, caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics, or pneumonic, caused by inhalation of infectious droplets. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe. It also has implications for the spread of plague in the modern world.

The evolution of brain size is a key factor in understanding the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain power is more complex than just the evolution of brain size. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is driven by the evolution of the number of neurons, which is the brain’s basic computational unit. The study also shows that the evolution of brain power is not only driven by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons in the brain. This study provides a more comprehensive picture of the evolution of brain power and its drivers.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy.

Actin filaments are the building blocks of the cytoskeleton, which is the network of filaments that provides the physical support to cells. Actin filaments are also the sites of many cellular processes, including cell division. In order to control the dynamics of actin filaments, cells have evolved a family of proteins that can sever actin filaments. However, how these proteins sever actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that the proteins of the ADF/cofilin family can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We also show that the severing rate is enhanced by a mechanical torque. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of how ADF/cofilin can control the dynamics of actin filaments in cells. This work also provides a general framework for understanding the role of mechanical forces in protein function.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. However, the mechanisms underlying this difference are unknown. We show that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for the development of obesity and for the design of food products. They also suggest that fructose may be a stronger trigger of food cravings than previously thought. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. They also provide a framework for the study of the history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 1,000 people, and is the first to show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in a social network. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social networks.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in the cell. The addition of chemical modifications to the mRNA sequence can have profound effects on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis.

This study shows that the subjective feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in biology. However, the drivers of this pattern have been debated. Here, we use a quantitative approach to test the relative importance of different hypotheses. We find that the aquatic lifestyle is the primary driver of the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals.

The common cold is one of the most common diseases in the world, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the cause of 5 to 10 million cases of the common cold in the United States alone each year. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature of 37 °C. Here, we show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of sensors to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This is the first example of a bacterial system that uses pili to measure the mechanical activity of the cell surface. We propose a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the activity of pili. This system is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it promotes the attachment of the bacterium to surfaces, which is essential for the formation of biofilms and the spread of the infection. This study thus provides a new example of how bacteria use pili for motility and sensing.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticide concentrations in surface water and sediments. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is now endemic. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife is a concern because of the potential for spillback into human populations. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is widespread in North America. We also show that the virus has spread between deer populations. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the inflammatory response is not well understood. Here, we show that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in the brain, and that Aβ is the primary stimulus for this response. We also show that the human brain is vulnerable to this neuron-derived inflammatory response. Thus, we identify the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. © 2014 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still lacking. We present a new approach to the study of the history of chicken domestication, based on a quantitative analysis of the faunal remains from the site of Maresha, Israel. Our results show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the Hellenistic period. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic use of chickens in the world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have studied the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein, in great detail. We have found that the folding process is not a single step but rather a series of steps. The steps are not independent of each other, but are connected.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a critical factor in the regulation of gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap formed by Np4 in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. We also show that the enzyme responsible for removing capped RNAs, RppH, is activated by stress and that it prefers to remove capped RNAs over their capped counterparts. This preference is due to a unique mechanism of substrate recognition that results in a one-nucleotide shift in the specificity of the enzyme. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that arginine deprivation could be a mechanism involved in the immunosuppression observed in sepsis. We found that arginine deprivation was associated with mitochondrial dysfunction, Treg expansion, and MDSC generation. We also found that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, could restore T cell function and proliferation and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This approach could be extended to other conditions in which immunosuppression is associated with mitochondrial dysfunction. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and space, and the dynamics of the system are characterized by a critical state. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not easy to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. This work provides opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new approach to control the properties of other materials. This work is expected to promote the development of diamond-based technologies.

The role of plant-derived antimicrobial peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not known. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide. The structure of the peptide was largely disordered and dynamic. It exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. The peptide penetrated the cell wall and cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The peptide was effective in spray-applied form against B. cinerea in tomato and tobacco plants. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during the male–female interface. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. Platelet function is altered in the common disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), and in VWD mouse models. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The results also suggest that the on-rate of VWF binding to platelets is regulated by force. This is a mechanism that is likely to be common in many proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied extensively. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. Here, we present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the first of its kind. We find that the virome is associated with many diseases, and that the association is stronger than the association with the bacteriome. This study is a major step toward understanding the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. We demonstrate the capability of this instrument in observing ACI processes. The observations provide substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. In this study, we use the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to reconstruct the temperature of the surface of the Earth over geological time. We find that the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous interpretations of the temperature of the surface of the Earth.

Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidneys. They are also involved in many diseases, including arrhythmias, epilepsy, and hypertension. Potassium channels are gated by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery are spatially related. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of potassium channels. It may also lead to the development of new drugs for treating diseases caused by potassium channel dysfunction. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are in a constant state of physical interaction, with the parasite using its antigens to alter the host cell’s physical properties. This finding could lead to the development of new strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not easy to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain. This opens up opportunities to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat influenza. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in the form of a tree, with each word in a sentence being part of a phrase. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a neural implementation of a merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is a bottom-up parser of the incoming language stream. Our findings have implications for the study of language in neuroimaging and neurophysiological studies. They also suggest that the brain may be a more complex device than previously thought.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for the development of the organism. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt signal. This is an important feature that may be used in other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major public health problem. It is caused by a combination of factors, including genetic predisposition, environmental factors, and the development of eating disorders. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may contribute to the development of obesity. This circuit is activated by electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, a region of the brain that is important in the regulation of feeding. We show that this circuit is important for the development of overeating. This circuit may be a target for the development of drugs to treat obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen is the primary factor limiting crop yields. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable manner. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in other cereal crops, and it can be extended to other plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a significant impact on agriculture.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is being rapidly deforested. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and deter deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these systems is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed deforestation alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 vaccines are needed worldwide to contain the pandemic. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a variant of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein RBD that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. This engineered RBD can be expressed in bacteria, and the resulting VLP can be used as a vaccine. This engineered RBD can be used in other vaccine formats, including subunit vaccines, and can be expressed in a wide range of hosts. This engineered RBD can also be used to generate vaccines against other coronaviruses. This engineered RBD can be used to generate vaccines against other coronaviruses. This engineered RBD can be used to generate vaccines against other coronaviruses.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the ALK receptor tyrosine kinase. Recently, we identified secreted proteins as ligands for ALK. Here, we show that these ligands are able to activate ALK/Ltk receptors in vitro and in vivo. Moreover, we show that these ligands are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish and Drosophila larvae. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/Ltk receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is the first study showing that ALK/Ltk receptors are involved in the development of neural crest derivatives. This finding may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in the history of human disease. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the evolution of plague during this critical period. Our results suggest that plague was not a commensal of the flea in the Eurasian Neolithic, and that the flea-adapted form of plague emerged later in the Bronze Age. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its ecology, and may have implications for the spread of plague in the past and in the future. This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. (PsycInfo Database Record

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is critical to the global climate. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of SOC. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reversing this trend remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that maintain or increase crop diversity, reduce soil disturbance, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and MAOM-C on Mollisols. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester soil C and highlight the importance of integrating livestock into grassland management. This work provides a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems that can sequester soil C and mitigate climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose a risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. We validated the risk assessment using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a critical resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators and is often used to infer the identity of the pollinator. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment and show that the same enzymes are involved in the production of red nectar in the distantly related hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. This work provides evidence for convergent evolution of a key trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species. This trait is likely to be important for the evolution of pollination in plants and may be a target for the development of novel insecticides. (Show more)

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations, invasions, and expansions of populations. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period between the migrations of the Celts and the arrival of the Slavs is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived during the Early Medieval period. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of these women was heterogeneous, and that they had a very high degree of admixture with populations from outside Europe. In addition, we found that many genes associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide new insights into the history of Europe and the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of modern Europeans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans and for developing strategies to prevent MERS-CoV transmission to humans. These

The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that mNGS can be used to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This study is a proof of concept for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The fidelity of this process is critical to the proper functioning of the cell. In humans, the lagging strand is replicated by pol δ, which requires the sliding clamp, PCNA, to maintain its stability during replication. We have developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications for the fidelity of lagging strand replication in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins. This work is a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in any city over time. This method can be used to monitor the physical changes in any city over time.

COVID-19 is a highly lethal disease. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. Tocilizumab, which is approved for rheumatoid arthritis, is the first drug that has been proved to be effective in the treatment of severe COVID-19. It is expected to be a new treatment option for severe COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal. The maintenance of copper homeostasis is essential for fungal growth and development, and is accomplished through a variety of mechanisms. Here we describe the discovery of a copper-binding isocyanide, xanthocillin, in Aspergillus fumigatus. Xanthocillin is secreted and has antimicrobial properties, and is induced in response to copper limitation. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for isocyanide-derived metabolites in the regulation of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of isocyanide-derived metabolites in the regulation of metal homeostasis in eukaryotes. (Read more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanism in the vicinity of the sample site. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sample suggests that the sediment was derived from the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The presence of amorphous precipitated silica, primary precipitates, and/or their diagenesis products in the sample suggests that the sediment was subjected to multiple aqueous infiltrations. The presence of post-lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrous sulfate suggests that the sediment was subjected to a single aqueous infiltration. The presence of magnetite suggests that the sediment was derived from a region with a history of magmatic activity. The presence of mixed-cation salts and oxides suggests that the sediment was subjected to multiple aqueous infiltrations. These results provide insights into the nature of the sediment source region and the history of aqueous alteration of the sediment. Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity, and the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in response to climate warming. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of temperate and boreal trees. We also show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is likely to increase frost damage in some regions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and is required for the development of colitis, whereas the other subset, which is deficient in IFN-γ, is required for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by the toxic effects of reactive oxygen species. We report a method to rapidly convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. These cells are toxic to motor neurons, and we find that the toxicity is driven by reactive oxygen species. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate reactive oxygen species-driven toxicity in ALS. This will accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human granulocytic anaplasmosis pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of the pathogen to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which binds the d-alanine residue of the bacterial cell wall and alters the permeability of the gut. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the evolution of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the study of the evolution of the tail in basal birds has been hindered by a lack of known diversity. Here, we describe a basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) and provide insights into the evolution of the tail in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. We show here that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that water vapor in the stratosphere increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color polymorphism has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two major populations, which have different biological and clinical characteristics. One of these populations, the cancer stem cell (CSC) population, is responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the tumor. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of CSCs. Our findings have implications for the development of new therapies for breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment in other historical documents. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter in understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion.
