Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific role of RORα remains unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune response in infected individuals. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0-Å resolution. The structure of the spike glycoprotein provides insight into the molecular basis of the receptor binding and fusion activities of the protein.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Fudenberg and Levine (1984) to the case of tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth for the total US population by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes. © 2020, The Author(s).

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure. We show that this is consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can release large amounts of carbon into the atmosphere. However, the effects of climate and human-driven changes in fire on the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of active fire management in mitigating climate change.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major player in host health, but the mechanisms that regulate its composition are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic bacterium of a squid, Vibrio fischeri, is maintained in a stable population by the host, which provides the bacterium with a specific glycan, chitin, just before dusk. This glycan is catabolized by the host, which is necessary for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which in turn enhances the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the composition of the gut microbiota, which may be important for the health of other animals. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly used to understand the world. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. We hope it will be used to improve the understanding of the world.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The origin of this disease is still debated, but the evidence points to the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors, via Asia, over a period of four centuries. Our results suggest that the disease did not establish itself in Europe, and that the climate was a key factor in the failure of the plague to establish itself in Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are also a major prey item for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, a disease has recently emerged that causes rapid mortality of asteroids. The disease is caused by a virus, which is transmitted by the sea stars. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP; IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, we show that the IL1RAP-targeting antibody can be used to treat primary human AML cells. Thus, the IL1RAP-targeting antibody is a promising candidate for clinical application. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment modality for AML. The results also provide a platform for the development of antibodies targeting other targets on candidate AML stem cells. This approach may lead to the development of more efficient and more effective therapies for AML. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. They also provide a framework for the study of the history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to improve the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that improve the antibody’s neutralizing activity against Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to mitigate the impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants on the global pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide critical information on crop status to the government, farmers, and the general public. However, the information they provide is subjective and qualitative, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this index to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert surveys in agricultural monitoring and forecasting. It also provides a new tool for the agricultural community to monitor and manage their crops. This work can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. © 2016, The Author(s).

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plastids. Here, we show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome and for the origin of eukaryotes.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of the 2015–2017 drought. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of anthropogenic climate change. This study is a step towards a better understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of extreme droughts. This knowledge is critical for the development of adaptation strategies.

The discovery of quasicrystals has revolutionized the study of solids. However, the conditions under which they form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. We show that the discovery of this new quasicrystal is linked to the history of the world.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth. It is powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The conversion of this energy is mediated by the modified tetrapyrroles, chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll. The formation of the fifth ring of these pigments is a key step in their biosynthesis. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which have remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we show that the two enzymes are members of the same protein superfamily, and that they are evolutionarily related. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a rodent model of MS. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the early stage of EAE, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of ASK1 in the development of EAE and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for EAE and other neurodegenerative diseases. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a large genetic component. The identification of the causal genes and the causal pathways is a major challenge in autism research. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of forgetting in learning and memory. This study is expected to contribute to the understanding of the genetic basis of autism and to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

This work is the first to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the public. It also provides the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in this regard. The results suggest that the prevalence of negativity biases is likely to be higher than previously thought, and that there is reason to reconsider the conventional wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in Stormorken syndrome. We also identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel and spontaneous bleeding in zebrafish embryos. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a model for the identification of new therapeutic targets in patients with Stormorken syndrome. (PsycINFO Database Record

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin in Drosophila causes non–cell-autonomous pathology, including loss of vulnerable neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates requires endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of neurodegenerative proteins and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly recognized as reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection, LTB4. MTX has no effect on the aminopeptidase function of LTA4H and therefore does not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The findings also provide a deeper understanding of the immunosuppressant protein MTX and its role in the immune system of bats. This study may also provide a new perspective for the study of the immune system of bats and the development of antiviral drugs. This article is

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. We also report the discovery of a new mechanism of action for SHMT inhibitors, which is rooted in defective glycine import. This mechanism of action may be applicable to other diseases, and may be a useful strategy for the design of new drugs. Thus, this work provides a framework for the design of new drugs for cancer and other diseases.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that this work will lead to a new generation of experiments in many-body physics with neutral atoms. This work is a significant step toward the realization of a new generation of quantum technologies. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the origin of the flowering plants has been hampered by the lack of fossils. Here, we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant that lived in the sea. Montsechia is an important fossil because it is the oldest known flowering plant with a complete flower.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are associated with a number of conditions in humans, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been estimated to be faster than that of RNA viruses, but the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses has been dated to the early 1800s. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is dated to ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the second genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising on a global scale, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of climate change and ocean dynamics. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is 0.084 mm/y2. This is in agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections. We also find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is 1.2 times larger than the ocean dynamics-driven acceleration. This finding is important for understanding the causes of sea level rise and for assessing the accuracy of climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing with age in America, but that it is also increasing with education. This is a new pattern, and it is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway of a defining species in a class of enzymes. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the mortality rate is high. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment prevented disease, inhibited virus replication, and reduced the severity of lung lesions. These data support the testing of remdesivir in a clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of particular importance in the context of the current outbreak. The availability of effective antiviral treatments would be critical to reduce the mortality rate of MERS and 2019-nCoV infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major player in host health, but the mechanisms that regulate its composition are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic bacterium of a squid, Vibrio fischeri, is maintained in a stable population by the host, which provides the bacterium with a specific glycan, chitin, just before dusk. This glycan is catabolized by the host, which is necessary for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which in turn enhances the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a new example of how the provision of a specific nutrient can regulate the composition of the gut microbiota. It also suggests that other hosts may use this mechanism to regulate the composition of their gut microbiota. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work is about the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. It is also about the importance of teachers’ relationships with students. We show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can be sustained. We also show that the quality of teachers’ relationships with students can be improved. These findings have implications for the way we think about and teach students in schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is known to cause mutagenesis and transcriptional stalling. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of the S proteins is required for virus entry into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. This finding is significant because it suggests that the first cleavages may be significant determinants of virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to reduce these emissions and improve population health. However, the food system is complex, and it is difficult to change people’s behavior. Here, we show that it is possible to nudge people toward more plant-based diets by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a year-long series of observational and experimental field studies. These results provide evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. They also provide a model for the development of future interventions to change people’s food choices. This work has implications for the food system, public health, and environmental sustainability.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to study the surfaceome of a panel of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step toward understanding the cell surface in cancer. This work is a significant step toward understanding the cell surface in cancer.

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that may be effective in increasing turnout. They also suggest that the effects of vote-by-mail are likely to be modest and that the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout may be positive or negative depending on the election and the characteristics of the electorate. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may be important for immune evasion and/or interference with the host antiviral response. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important. Unfortunately, it is very difficult to decide which associations are important. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help researchers to make better use of the data that they have.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most important cell type in the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult, and the development of ECs has been poorly understood. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts. We found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a critical factor for the generation of ECs. ETV2 is expressed in the endothelium of many organs, including the liver, and is essential for the formation of vascular networks in the liver. Our study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the formation of vascular networks. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study may also lead to the development of new therapies for vascular disorders. Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in the development and function of many tissues. In the past few years, two new RTKs have been discovered that are involved in cancer. However, the physiological role of these two RTKs has not been characterized. Here, we show that the zebrafish ortholog of one of these RTKs, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk), is involved in pigment development. We also show that the two ligands of Alk, augmentor-α1 and augmentor-α2, are essential for zebrafish pigment development. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Alk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands activate Alk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the physiological role of Alk and augmentor ligands in vivo. These findings may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the transcription factor Pax6 was down-regulated and its nuclear localization was lost in STING-βKO β-cells. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanism of STING in the pathogenesis of T2D. Moreover, they may lead to the development of STING-targeted therapies for T2D. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of STING-targeted therapies for other diseases. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual occurrence of influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which is a unique feature of the virus. This genome organization offers evolutionary advantages, but it also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is sequence specific and sequence dependent. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings have implications for the understanding of the molecular mechanisms of viral packaging and might also lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the disturbed flow-induced induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in ECs. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in ECs. In addition, inhibition of YAP/TAZ translation is sufficient to reduce the size of atherosclerotic lesions in vivo. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the disturbed flow-induced induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in ECs and atherosclerotic lesion development. These findings may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in other cities and to study the physical dynamics of cities in general. We hope that our method will be useful to urban researchers and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Zika virus (ZIKV) has spread to more than 100 countries, causing a global health concern. The virus has been associated with microcephaly and other neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV transmission in a primate model. We show that the model is well-behaved and can be used to estimate the basic reproductive number R0, the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, and the effect of antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of the virus. We also provide estimates of the number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. These estimates can be used to assess the effect of antiviral treatment on the virus burden in the blood. Our results can be used to guide the development of antiviral treatment strategies. Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host increases during heat stress, which is compensated by the catabolism of amino acids. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier between the host and the environment. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. The microbiome, in turn, triggers a regenerative response in the tumor, leading to a vicious cycle. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. We also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between tumors, the microbiome, and the regenerative response, and it may lead to the development of new strategies to control tumor growth. Chemotherapy is a mainstay of treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to this therapy is common. We find that treatment of breast cancer cells with chemotherapy enhances the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1. ROR1 expression is also induced by activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). ROR1 expression is enriched in breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) and correlates with the capacity of these tumors to metastasize. Finally, treatment of mice bearing breast cancer PDXs with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, ROR1 may be a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is linked to a unique, ∼192-y series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where rivers are most important for food security. Our data can be used to identify areas of high biodiversity and high fishery dependence, which can inform conservation and management efforts. This analysis highlights the importance of inland fisheries in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, and underscores the need to protect these resources to ensure food security and biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve high-energy aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. The ability to regenerate after injury is a critical feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is highly resistant to regeneration, and regeneration is even rarer in the PNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway mediating regeneration in the CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult CNS. Moreover, our study suggests that the adult nervous system has a much greater regenerative capacity than previously thought.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in populations. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are more concentrated in the promoter regions of genes than in the coding regions, and they are more likely to terminate in exons than in introns. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This study provides a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant, which is an important model for studying the evolution of recombination and the genetic basis of phenotypic variation. The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in activity reflecting the activity of a large number of functionally distinct networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the organization of brain function. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN was subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was reduced in advanced Parkinson’s disease. This work provides a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of the transcriptome. Here we describe a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). We show that NAD-modified mRNAs are found in mitochondria and in the nucleus, and that they are enriched in mitochondrial transcripts. This finding suggests that NAD+ may be a general modification of the nuclear transcriptome.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The molecular mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here, we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes. These DNA-me differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These findings may help to identify new targets for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in TNBC progression and drug sensitivity has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Thus, our study provides insights into the role of FSIP1 in TNBC progression and drug sensitivity. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with high mortality and morbidity. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. This article is protected by copyright. The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. Many of these chemicals are nitrogenous, meaning that they contain nitrogen. The biosynthetic pathways for many of these nitrogenous volatiles are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of other nitrogenous chemicals in Nicotiana benthamiana, providing a proof of principle for the use of this gene in the production of other nitrogenous chemicals in plants. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming in the design of conservation and restoration strategies. This is critical given that biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment, including the location of the animal’s home and the direction of travel. The organization of MEC neurons is critical for this encoding. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal’s location, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which encode the direction of travel and the location of objects in the environment. These data provide a detailed map of the topographic organization of MEC neurons that will be useful for understanding the encoding of spatial information in the brain.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model for understanding the flowering regulation of a parasitic plant. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in the striatum form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a unique view of the dopamine-containing nigral system and its connections. It also provides a model for the study of other systems in the brain.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the way we read minds is by looking at the speed at which we respond to others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the normal function of the SAN. Our results reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These findings have implications for the understanding of the pathophysiology of heart failure and atrial fibrillation. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivory has been debated. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for allene oxide synthase or CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1. This interaction between Si and JA was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivory. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for macrophage-specific alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity, which is important for the metabolism of alkylglycerols. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings may lead to a better understanding of macrophage biology and may be of importance for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it enables the binding of linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the primary source of food and medicine for the human population. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of DNA nanostructures as a delivery platform for biomolecules to plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in nearshore areas. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient pollution and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to these areas. This could improve the health of nearshore ecosystems and reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable aquatic resources.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system driven by a random force. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of chemical networks in thermodynamic environments.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor can change the dynamics of the brain, leading to changes in the EEG. We use a mathematical model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain the EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. Finally, we show that the same changes in the same synaptic parameters can lead to overt EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by the antibody. They also provide a framework for the development of new therapies for this devastating disease. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event. To understand the causes of past abrupt warming events, it is important to understand the processes that led to past warming events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was caused by a combination of factors, including a change in the ocean circulation, a change in the carbon cycle, and an increase in nutrient supply. These results provide insights into the processes that led to the current rapid warming and can be used to better understand the causes of past abrupt warming events.

We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Certification had no impact on deforestation in peatlands because certification did not reduce the area of forest remaining within plantations. The exocyst complex is essential to the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In other vertebrates, sex is determined by multiple loci, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination loci on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that multiple sex determination loci can produce a modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolution of sex determination alleles. This modularity can also be used to understand the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of sex determination in vertebrates.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and Fe is a key redox factor. We sought to understand the impact of Fe on the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels impact the retina. In particular, we show that Fe promotes the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a major contributor to the oxidative stress and photodamage of the retina. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy to protect the retina from photodamage. This strategy could be applied to other tissues challenged by Fe, such as the brain. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization is a key process in the diversification of ecosystems. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the evolution of specialization on different prey types. Our findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of specialization in predators, and how this process has shaped the present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. We also report the discovery of a new mechanism of action for SHMT inhibitors, which is rooted in defective glycine import. This mechanism of action may be applicable to other diseases, and may be a useful strategy for the design of new drugs. Thus, this work provides a framework for the design of new drugs for cancer and other diseases.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the impacts of this process on people’s diets are not well understood. We show that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of micronutrients. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and health.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
